trans-unit.source: Theme resources in XAML are a set of resources that apply different values depending on which system theme is active.
trans-unit.target: Theme resources in XAML are a set of resources that apply different values depending on which system theme is active.

trans-unit.source: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: Theme resources in XAML are a set of resources that apply different values depending on which system theme is active.
trans-unit.target: Theme resources in XAML are a set of resources that apply different values depending on which system theme is active.

trans-unit.source: There are 3 themes that the XAML framework supports: "Light", "Dark", and "HighContrast".
trans-unit.target: There are 3 themes that the XAML framework supports: "Light", "Dark", and "HighContrast".

trans-unit.source: This topic assumes that you have read [ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references](resourcedictionary-and-xaml-resource-references.md).
trans-unit.target: This topic assumes that you have read [ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references](resourcedictionary-and-xaml-resource-references.md).

trans-unit.source: How theme resources differ from static resources
trans-unit.target: How theme resources differ from static resources

trans-unit.source: There are two XAML markup extensions that can reference a XAML resource from an existing XAML resource dictionary: [{StaticResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/staticresource-markup-extension.md) and [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md).
trans-unit.target: There are two XAML markup extensions that can reference a XAML resource from an existing XAML resource dictionary: [{StaticResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/staticresource-markup-extension.md) and [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md).

trans-unit.source: Evaluation of a [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) occurs when the app loads and subsequently each time the theme changes at runtime.
trans-unit.target: Evaluation of a [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) occurs when the app loads and subsequently each time the theme changes at runtime.

trans-unit.source: This is typically the result of the user changing their device settings or from a programmatic change within the app that alters its current theme.
trans-unit.target: This is typically the result of the user changing their device settings or from a programmatic change within the app that alters its current theme.

trans-unit.source: In contrast, a [{StaticResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/staticresource-markup-extension.md) is evaluated only when the XAML is first loaded by the app.
trans-unit.target: In contrast, a [{StaticResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/staticresource-markup-extension.md) is evaluated only when the XAML is first loaded by the app.

trans-unit.source: It’s similar to a find and replace in your XAML with the actual runtime value at app launch.
trans-unit.target: It’s similar to a find and replace in your XAML with the actual runtime value at app launch.

trans-unit.source: Theme resources and where they fit in the resource dictionary structure
trans-unit.target: Theme resources and where they fit in the resource dictionary structure

trans-unit.source: Each theme resource is part of the XAML file themeresources.xaml.
trans-unit.target: Each theme resource is part of the XAML file themeresources.xaml.

trans-unit.source: For design purposes, themeresources.xaml is available in the \\(Program Files)\\Windows Kits\\10\\DesignTime\\CommonConfiguration\\Neutral\\UAP\\<SDK version>\\Generic folder from a Windows Software Development Kit (SDK) installation.
trans-unit.target: For design purposes, themeresources.xaml is available in the \\(Program Files)\\Windows Kits\\10\\DesignTime\\CommonConfiguration\\Neutral\\UAP\\<SDK version>\\Generic folder from a Windows Software Development Kit (SDK) installation.

trans-unit.source: The resource dictionaries in themeresources.xaml are also reproduced in generic.xaml in the same directory.
trans-unit.target: The resource dictionaries in themeresources.xaml are also reproduced in generic.xaml in the same directory.

trans-unit.source: **Note**  The Windows Runtime doesn't use these physical files for runtime lookup.
trans-unit.target: **Note**  The Windows Runtime doesn't use these physical files for runtime lookup.

trans-unit.source: That's why they are specifically in a DesignTime folder, and they aren't copied into apps by default.
trans-unit.target: That's why they are specifically in a DesignTime folder, and they aren't copied into apps by default.

trans-unit.source: Instead, these resource dictionaries exist in memory as part of the Windows Runtime itself, and your app's XAML resource references to theme resources (or system resources) resolve there at runtime.
trans-unit.target: Instead, these resource dictionaries exist in memory as part of the Windows Runtime itself, and your app's XAML resource references to theme resources (or system resources) resolve there at runtime.

trans-unit.source: Follow these guidelines when you define and consume your own custom theme resources.
trans-unit.target: Follow these guidelines when you define and consume your own custom theme resources.

trans-unit.source: Specify theme dictionaries for both "Light" and "Dark" in addition to your "HighContrast" dictionary.
trans-unit.target: Specify theme dictionaries for both "Light" and "Dark" in addition to your "HighContrast" dictionary.

trans-unit.source: Although you can create a [**ResourceDictionary**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208794) with "Default" as the key, it’s preferred to be explicit and instead use "Light", "Dark", and "HighContrast".
trans-unit.target: Although you can create a [**ResourceDictionary**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208794) with "Default" as the key, it’s preferred to be explicit and instead use "Light", "Dark", and "HighContrast".

trans-unit.source: Use the [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) in: Styles, Setters, Control templates, Property setters, and Animations.
trans-unit.target: Use the [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) in: Styles, Setters, Control templates, Property setters, and Animations.

trans-unit.source: Use the [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) in your resource definitions inside your [**ThemeDictionaries**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208807).
trans-unit.target: Use the [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) in your resource definitions inside your [**ThemeDictionaries**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208807).

trans-unit.source: EXCEPTION: it is alright to use the [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) to reference resources that are agnostic to the app theme in your [**ThemeDictionaries**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208807).
trans-unit.target: EXCEPTION: it is alright to use the [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) to reference resources that are agnostic to the app theme in your [**ThemeDictionaries**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208807).

trans-unit.source: Examples of these resources are accent color resources like `SystemAccentColor`, or system color resources, which are typically prefixed with "SystemColor" like `SystemColorButtonFaceColor`.
trans-unit.target: Examples of these resources are accent color resources like `SystemAccentColor`, or system color resources, which are typically prefixed with "SystemColor" like `SystemColorButtonFaceColor`.

trans-unit.source: **Caution** If you don’t follow these guidelines, you might see unexpected behavior related to themes in your app.
trans-unit.target: **Caution** If you don’t follow these guidelines, you might see unexpected behavior related to themes in your app.

trans-unit.source: For more info, see the [Troubleshooting theme resources](#troubleshooting_theme_resources) section.
trans-unit.target: For more info, see the [Troubleshooting theme resources](#troubleshooting_theme_resources) section.

trans-unit.source: The XAML color ramp and theme-dependent brushes
trans-unit.target: The XAML color ramp and theme-dependent brushes

trans-unit.source: The combined set of colors for "Light", "Dark", and "HighContrast" themes make up the *Windows color ramp* in XAML.
trans-unit.target: The combined set of colors for "Light", "Dark", and "HighContrast" themes make up the *Windows color ramp* in XAML.

trans-unit.source: Whether you want to modify the system themes, or apply a system theme to your own XAML elements, it’s important to understand how the color resources are structured.
trans-unit.target: Whether you want to modify the system themes, or apply a system theme to your own XAML elements, it’s important to understand how the color resources are structured.

trans-unit.source: The XAML framework provides a set of named [**Color**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh673723) resources with values that are tailored for the "Light" and "Dark" themes.
trans-unit.target: The XAML framework provides a set of named [**Color**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh673723) resources with values that are tailored for the "Light" and "Dark" themes.

trans-unit.source: The keys you use to reference these follow the naming format: `System[Simple Light/Dark Name]Color`.
trans-unit.target: The keys you use to reference these follow the naming format: `System[Simple Light/Dark Name]Color`.

trans-unit.source: This table lists the key, simple name, and string representation of the color (using the \#aarrggbb format) for the "Light" and "Dark" resources provided by the XAML framework.
trans-unit.target: This table lists the key, simple name, and string representation of the color (using the \#aarrggbb format) for the "Light" and "Dark" resources provided by the XAML framework.

trans-unit.source: The key is used to reference the resource in an app.
trans-unit.target: The key is used to reference the resource in an app.

trans-unit.source: The "Simple light/dark name" is used as part of the brush naming convention that we explain later.
trans-unit.target: The "Simple light/dark name" is used as part of the brush naming convention that we explain later.

trans-unit.source: In addition to the set of resources provided by the XAML framework, there's a set of color values derived from the Windows system palette.
trans-unit.target: In addition to the set of resources provided by the XAML framework, there's a set of color values derived from the Windows system palette.

trans-unit.source: These colors are not specific to the Windows Runtime or Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
trans-unit.target: These colors are not specific to the Windows Runtime or Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

trans-unit.source: However, many of the XAML [**Brush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br228076) resources consume these colors when the system is operating (and the app is running) using the "HighContrast" theme.
trans-unit.target: However, many of the XAML [**Brush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br228076) resources consume these colors when the system is operating (and the app is running) using the "HighContrast" theme.

trans-unit.source: The XAML framework provides these system-wide colors as keyed resources.
trans-unit.target: The XAML framework provides these system-wide colors as keyed resources.

trans-unit.source: The keys follow the naming format: `SystemColor[name]Color`.
trans-unit.target: The keys follow the naming format: `SystemColor[name]Color`.

trans-unit.source: This table lists the system-wide colors that XAML provides as resource objects derived from the Windows system palette.
trans-unit.target: This table lists the system-wide colors that XAML provides as resource objects derived from the Windows system palette.

trans-unit.source: The "Ease of Access name" column shows how color is labeled in the Windows settings UI.
trans-unit.target: The "Ease of Access name" column shows how color is labeled in the Windows settings UI.

trans-unit.source: The "Simple HighContrast name" column is a one word description of how the color is applied across the XAML common controls.
trans-unit.target: The "Simple HighContrast name" column is a one word description of how the color is applied across the XAML common controls.

trans-unit.source: It's used as part of the brush naming convention that we explain later.
trans-unit.target: It's used as part of the brush naming convention that we explain later.

trans-unit.source: The "Initial default" column shows the values you'd get if the system is not running in high contrast at all.
trans-unit.target: The "Initial default" column shows the values you'd get if the system is not running in high contrast at all.

trans-unit.source: Windows provides different high-contrast themes, and enables the user to set the specific colors to for their high-contrast settings through the Ease of Access Center, as shown here.
trans-unit.target: Windows provides different high-contrast themes, and enables the user to set the specific colors to for their high-contrast settings through the Ease of Access Center, as shown here.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, it's not possible to provide a definitive list of high-contrast color values.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, it's not possible to provide a definitive list of high-contrast color values.

trans-unit.source: The Windows high contrast settings UI
trans-unit.target: The Windows high contrast settings UI

trans-unit.source: For more info about supporting high-contrast themes, see [High-contrast themes](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/mt244346).
trans-unit.target: For more info about supporting high-contrast themes, see [High-contrast themes](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/mt244346).

trans-unit.source: In addition to the system high-contrast theme colors, the system accent color is provided as a special color resource using the key `SystemAccentColor`.
trans-unit.target: In addition to the system high-contrast theme colors, the system accent color is provided as a special color resource using the key `SystemAccentColor`.

trans-unit.source: At runtime, this resource gets the color that the user has specified as the accent color in the Windows personalization settings.
trans-unit.target: At runtime, this resource gets the color that the user has specified as the accent color in the Windows personalization settings.

trans-unit.source: **Note**  It’s possible to override the system color resources for high-contrast color and accent color by creating resources with the same names, but it’s a best practice to respect the user’s color choices, especially for high-contrast settings.
trans-unit.target: **Note**  It’s possible to override the system color resources for high-contrast color and accent color by creating resources with the same names, but it’s a best practice to respect the user’s color choices, especially for high-contrast settings.

trans-unit.source: The color resources shown in the preceding sections are used to set the [**Color**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br242963) property of [**SolidColorBrush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br242962) resources in the system theme resource dictionaries.
trans-unit.target: The color resources shown in the preceding sections are used to set the [**Color**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br242963) property of [**SolidColorBrush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br242962) resources in the system theme resource dictionaries.

trans-unit.source: You use the brush resources to apply the color to XAML elements.
trans-unit.target: You use the brush resources to apply the color to XAML elements.

trans-unit.source: The keys for the brush resources follow the naming format: `SystemControl[Simple HighContrast name][Simple light/dark name]Brush`.
trans-unit.target: The keys for the brush resources follow the naming format: `SystemControl[Simple HighContrast name][Simple light/dark name]Brush`.

trans-unit.source: Let’s look at how the color value for this brush is determined at run-time.
trans-unit.target: Let’s look at how the color value for this brush is determined at run-time.

trans-unit.source: In the "Light" and "Dark" resource dictionaries, this brush is defined like this:
trans-unit.target: In the "Light" and "Dark" resource dictionaries, this brush is defined like this:

trans-unit.source: In the "HighContrast" resource dictionary, this brush is defined like this:
trans-unit.target: In the "HighContrast" resource dictionary, this brush is defined like this:

trans-unit.source: When this brush is applied to a XAML element, its color is determined at run-time by the current theme, as shown in this table.
trans-unit.target: When this brush is applied to a XAML element, its color is determined at run-time by the current theme, as shown in this table.

trans-unit.source: The color specified in settings for the button background.
trans-unit.target: The color specified in settings for the button background.

trans-unit.source: You can use the `SystemControl[Simple HighContrast name][Simple light/dark name]Brush` naming scheme to determine which brush to apply to your own XAML elements.
trans-unit.target: You can use the `SystemControl[Simple HighContrast name][Simple light/dark name]Brush` naming scheme to determine which brush to apply to your own XAML elements.

trans-unit.source: **Note**  Not every combination of \[*Simple HighContrast name*\]\[*Simple light/dark name*\] is provided as a brush resource.
trans-unit.target: **Note**  Not every combination of \[*Simple HighContrast name*\]\[*Simple light/dark name*\] is provided as a brush resource.

trans-unit.source: The themeresources.xaml file defines several resources that define a [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208849) that you can apply to text containers in your UI, specifically for either [**TextBlock**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209652) or [**RichTextBlock**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227565).
trans-unit.target: The themeresources.xaml file defines several resources that define a [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208849) that you can apply to text containers in your UI, specifically for either [**TextBlock**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209652) or [**RichTextBlock**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227565).

trans-unit.source: These are not the default implicit styles.
trans-unit.target: These are not the default implicit styles.

trans-unit.source: They are provided to make it easier for you to create XAML UI definitions that match the *Windows type ramp* documented in [Guidelines for fonts](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh700394).
trans-unit.target: They are provided to make it easier for you to create XAML UI definitions that match the *Windows type ramp* documented in [Guidelines for fonts](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh700394).

trans-unit.source: These styles are for text attributes that you want applied to the whole text container.
trans-unit.target: These styles are for text attributes that you want applied to the whole text container.

trans-unit.source: If you want styles applied just to sections of the text, set attributes on the text elements within the container, such as on a [**Run**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209959) in [**TextBlock.Inlines**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209668) or on a [**Paragraph**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br244503) in [**RichTextBlock.Blocks**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br244347).
trans-unit.target: If you want styles applied just to sections of the text, set attributes on the text elements within the container, such as on a [**Run**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209959) in [**TextBlock.Inlines**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209668) or on a [**Paragraph**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br244503) in [**RichTextBlock.Blocks**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br244347).

trans-unit.source: The styles look like this when applied to a [**TextBlock**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209652):
trans-unit.target: The styles look like this when applied to a [**TextBlock**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209652):

trans-unit.source: Supplies the common properties for all the other [**TextBlock**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209652) container styles.
trans-unit.target: Supplies the common properties for all the other [**TextBlock**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209652) container styles.

trans-unit.source: Supplies the common properties for all the other [**RichTextBlock**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227565) container styles.
trans-unit.target: Supplies the common properties for all the other [**RichTextBlock**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227565) container styles.

trans-unit.source: **Note**   The [**RichTextBlock**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227565) styles don't have all the text ramp styles that [**TextBlock**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209652) does, mainly because the block-based document object model for **RichTextBlock** makes it easier to set attributes on the individual text elements.
trans-unit.target: **Note**   The [**RichTextBlock**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227565) styles don't have all the text ramp styles that [**TextBlock**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209652) does, mainly because the block-based document object model for **RichTextBlock** makes it easier to set attributes on the individual text elements.

trans-unit.source: Also, setting [**TextBlock.Text**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209676) using the XAML content property introduces a situation where there is no text element to style and thus you'd have to style the container.
trans-unit.target: Also, setting [**TextBlock.Text**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209676) using the XAML content property introduces a situation where there is no text element to style and thus you'd have to style the container.

trans-unit.source: That isn't an issue for **RichTextBlock** because its text content always has to be in specific text elements like [**Paragraph**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br244503), which is where you might apply XAML styles for page header, page subheader and similar text ramp definitions.
trans-unit.target: That isn't an issue for **RichTextBlock** because its text content always has to be in specific text elements like [**Paragraph**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br244503), which is where you might apply XAML styles for page header, page subheader and similar text ramp definitions.

trans-unit.source: There's an additional set of keyed [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208849) definitions you can apply to style a [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) differently than its default implicit style.
trans-unit.target: There's an additional set of keyed [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208849) definitions you can apply to style a [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) differently than its default implicit style.

trans-unit.source: Apply this style to a [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) when you need to show text that a user can click to take action.
trans-unit.target: Apply this style to a [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) when you need to show text that a user can click to take action.

trans-unit.source: The text is styled using the current accent color to distinguish it as interactive and has focus rectangles that work well for text.
trans-unit.target: The text is styled using the current accent color to distinguish it as interactive and has focus rectangles that work well for text.

trans-unit.source: Unlike the implicit style of a [**HyperlinkButton**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br242739), the **TextBlockButtonStyle** does not underline the text.
trans-unit.target: Unlike the implicit style of a [**HyperlinkButton**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br242739), the **TextBlockButtonStyle** does not underline the text.

trans-unit.source: The template also styles the presented text to use **SystemControlHyperlinkBaseMediumBrush** (for "PointerOver" state), **SystemControlHighlightBaseMediumLowBrush** (for "Pressed" state) and **SystemControlDisabledBaseLowBrush** (for "Disabled" state).
trans-unit.target: The template also styles the presented text to use **SystemControlHyperlinkBaseMediumBrush** (for "PointerOver" state), **SystemControlHighlightBaseMediumLowBrush** (for "Pressed" state) and **SystemControlDisabledBaseLowBrush** (for "Disabled" state).

trans-unit.source: Here's a [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) with the **TextBlockButtonStyle** resource applied to it.
trans-unit.target: Here's a [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) with the **TextBlockButtonStyle** resource applied to it.

trans-unit.source: A button styled to look like text
trans-unit.target: A button styled to look like text

trans-unit.source: This [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208849) provides a complete template for a [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) that can be the navigation back button for a navigation app.
trans-unit.target: This [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208849) provides a complete template for a [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) that can be the navigation back button for a navigation app.

trans-unit.source: It includes theme resource references that make this button use the Segoe MDL2 Assets symbol font, so you should use a [**Symbol**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn252842) value as the content rather than text.
trans-unit.target: It includes theme resource references that make this button use the Segoe MDL2 Assets symbol font, so you should use a [**Symbol**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn252842) value as the content rather than text.

trans-unit.source: The default dimensions are 40 x 40 pixels.
trans-unit.target: The default dimensions are 40 x 40 pixels.

trans-unit.source: To tailor the styling you can either explicitly set the [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208718), [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208751), [**FontSize**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209406), and other properties on your **Button** or create a derived style using [**BasedOn**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208852).
trans-unit.target: To tailor the styling you can either explicitly set the [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208718), [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208751), [**FontSize**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209406), and other properties on your **Button** or create a derived style using [**BasedOn**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208852).

trans-unit.source: Here's a [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) with the **NavigationBackButtonNormalStyle** resource applied to it.
trans-unit.target: Here's a [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) with the **NavigationBackButtonNormalStyle** resource applied to it.

trans-unit.source: A button styled as a back button
trans-unit.target: A button styled as a back button

trans-unit.source: This [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208849) provides a complete template for a [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) that can be the navigation back button for a navigation app.
trans-unit.target: This [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208849) provides a complete template for a [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) that can be the navigation back button for a navigation app.

trans-unit.source: It's similar to **NavigationBackButtonNormalStyle**, but its dimensions are 30 by 30 pixels.
trans-unit.target: It's similar to **NavigationBackButtonNormalStyle**, but its dimensions are 30 by 30 pixels.

trans-unit.source: Here's a [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) with the **NavigationBackButtonSmallStyle** resource applied to it.
trans-unit.target: Here's a [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) with the **NavigationBackButtonSmallStyle** resource applied to it.

trans-unit.source: If you don’t follow the [guidelines for using theme resources](#guidelines_for_using_theme_resources), you might see unexpected behavior related to themes in your app.
trans-unit.target: If you don’t follow the [guidelines for using theme resources](#guidelines_for_using_theme_resources), you might see unexpected behavior related to themes in your app.

trans-unit.source: For example, when you open a light-themed flyout, parts of your dark-themed app also change as if they were in the light theme.
trans-unit.target: For example, when you open a light-themed flyout, parts of your dark-themed app also change as if they were in the light theme.

trans-unit.source: Or if you navigate to a light-themed page and then navigate back, the original dark-themed page (or parts of it) now looks as though it is in the light theme.
trans-unit.target: Or if you navigate to a light-themed page and then navigate back, the original dark-themed page (or parts of it) now looks as though it is in the light theme.

trans-unit.source: Typically, these types of issues occur when you provide a "Default" theme and a "HighContrast" theme to support high-contrast scenarios, and then use both "Light" and "Dark" themes in different parts of your app.
trans-unit.target: Typically, these types of issues occur when you provide a "Default" theme and a "HighContrast" theme to support high-contrast scenarios, and then use both "Light" and "Dark" themes in different parts of your app.

trans-unit.source: For example, consider this theme dictionary definition:
trans-unit.target: For example, consider this theme dictionary definition:

trans-unit.source: You want to change the color pointed to by `myBrush` when in high-contrast, but when not in high-contrast, you rely on the [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) to make sure that `myBrush` points to the right color for your theme.
trans-unit.target: You want to change the color pointed to by `myBrush` when in high-contrast, but when not in high-contrast, you rely on the [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) to make sure that `myBrush` points to the right color for your theme.

trans-unit.source: If your app never has [**FrameworkElement.RequestedTheme**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn298515) set on elements within its visual tree, this will typically work as expected.
trans-unit.target: If your app never has [**FrameworkElement.RequestedTheme**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn298515) set on elements within its visual tree, this will typically work as expected.

trans-unit.source: However, you run into problems in your app as soon as you start to re-theme different parts of your visual tree.
trans-unit.target: However, you run into problems in your app as soon as you start to re-theme different parts of your visual tree.

trans-unit.source: The problem occurs because brushes are shared resources, unlike most other XAML types.
trans-unit.target: The problem occurs because brushes are shared resources, unlike most other XAML types.

trans-unit.source: If you have 2 elements in XAML sub-trees with different themes that reference the same brush resource, then as the framework walks each sub-tree to update its [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) expressions, changes to the shared brush resource are reflected in the other sub-tree, which is not your intended result.
trans-unit.target: If you have 2 elements in XAML sub-trees with different themes that reference the same brush resource, then as the framework walks each sub-tree to update its [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) expressions, changes to the shared brush resource are reflected in the other sub-tree, which is not your intended result.

trans-unit.source: To fix this, replace the "Default" dictionary with separate theme dictionaries for both "Light" and "Dark" themes in addition to "HighContrast":
trans-unit.target: To fix this, replace the "Default" dictionary with separate theme dictionaries for both "Light" and "Dark" themes in addition to "HighContrast":

trans-unit.source: However, problems still occur if any of these resources are referenced in inherited properties like [**Foreground**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209414).
trans-unit.target: However, problems still occur if any of these resources are referenced in inherited properties like [**Foreground**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209414).

trans-unit.source: Your custom control template might specify the foreground color of an element using the [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md), but when the framework propagates the inherited value to child elements, it provides a direct reference to the resource that was resolved by the {ThemeResource} markup extension expression.
trans-unit.target: Your custom control template might specify the foreground color of an element using the [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md), but when the framework propagates the inherited value to child elements, it provides a direct reference to the resource that was resolved by the {ThemeResource} markup extension expression.

trans-unit.source: This causes problems when the framework processes theme changes as it walks your control's visual tree.
trans-unit.target: This causes problems when the framework processes theme changes as it walks your control's visual tree.

trans-unit.source: It re-evaluates the {ThemeResource} markup extension expression to get a new brush resource but doesn’t yet propagate this reference down to the children of your control; this happens later, such as during the next measure pass.
trans-unit.target: It re-evaluates the {ThemeResource} markup extension expression to get a new brush resource but doesn’t yet propagate this reference down to the children of your control; this happens later, such as during the next measure pass.

trans-unit.source: As a result, after walking the control visual tree in response to a theme change, the framework walks the children and updates any [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) expressions set on them, or on objects set on their properties.
trans-unit.target: As a result, after walking the control visual tree in response to a theme change, the framework walks the children and updates any [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) expressions set on them, or on objects set on their properties.

trans-unit.source: This is where the problem occurs; the framework walks the brush resource and because it specifies its color using a {ThemeResource} markup extension, it's re-evaluated.
trans-unit.target: This is where the problem occurs; the framework walks the brush resource and because it specifies its color using a {ThemeResource} markup extension, it's re-evaluated.

trans-unit.source: At this point, the framework appears to have polluted your theme dictionary because it now has a resource from one dictionary that has its color set from another dictionary.
trans-unit.target: At this point, the framework appears to have polluted your theme dictionary because it now has a resource from one dictionary that has its color set from another dictionary.

trans-unit.source: To fix this problem, use the [{StaticResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/staticresource-markup-extension.md) instead of [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md).
trans-unit.target: To fix this problem, use the [{StaticResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/staticresource-markup-extension.md) instead of [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md).

trans-unit.source: With the guidelines applied, the theme dictionaries look like this:
trans-unit.target: With the guidelines applied, the theme dictionaries look like this:

trans-unit.source: Notice that the [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) is still used in the "HighContrast" dictionary instead of [{StaticResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/staticresource-markup-extension.md).
trans-unit.target: Notice that the [{ThemeResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/themeresource-markup-extension.md) is still used in the "HighContrast" dictionary instead of [{StaticResource} markup extension](../xaml-platform/staticresource-markup-extension.md).

trans-unit.source: This situation falls under the exception given earlier in the guidelines.
trans-unit.target: This situation falls under the exception given earlier in the guidelines.

trans-unit.source: Most of the brush values that are used for the "HighContrast" theme are using color choices that are globally controlled by the system, but exposed to XAML as a specially-named resource (those prefixed with ‘SystemColor’ in the name).
trans-unit.target: Most of the brush values that are used for the "HighContrast" theme are using color choices that are globally controlled by the system, but exposed to XAML as a specially-named resource (those prefixed with ‘SystemColor’ in the name).

trans-unit.source: The system enables the user to set the specific colors that should be used for their high contrast settings through the Ease of Access Center.
trans-unit.target: The system enables the user to set the specific colors that should be used for their high contrast settings through the Ease of Access Center.

trans-unit.source: Those color choices are applied to the specially-named resources.
trans-unit.target: Those color choices are applied to the specially-named resources.

trans-unit.source: The XAML framework uses the same theme changed event to also update these brushes when it detects they’ve changed at the system level.
trans-unit.target: The XAML framework uses the same theme changed event to also update these brushes when it detects they’ve changed at the system level.

trans-unit.source: This is why the {ThemeResource} markup extension is used here.
trans-unit.target: This is why the {ThemeResource} markup extension is used here.

trans-unit.source: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
trans-unit.target: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

trans-unit.source: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the [archived documentation](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132).
trans-unit.target: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the [archived documentation](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132).
